title: Papacy
intro: The question we'll explore is whether the doctrine of the papacy is probable. More specifically, we'll look for evidence for and against a claim about the "minimalist view" of the Papacy: that the pope has some authority over the rest of the bishops and the Church in general.

evidence.short: Acts 10:9–16: God changed kosher laws and gentile exclusion through Peter
evidence.details: 9 About noon the next day, as they were on their journey and approaching the city, Peter went up on the roof to pray. 10 He became hungry and wanted something to eat, and while it was being prepared he fell into a trance. 11 He saw the heaven opened and something like a large sheet coming down, being lowered to the ground by its four corners. 12 In it were all kinds of four-footed creatures and reptiles and birds of the air. 13 Then he heard a voice saying, “Get up, Peter; kill and eat.” 14 But Peter said, “By no means, Lord, for I have never eaten anything that is profane or unclean.” 15 The voice said to him again, a second time, “What God has made clean, you must not call profane.” 16 This happened three times, and the thing was suddenly taken up to heaven.

5 But a man named Ananias, with the consent of his wife Sapphira, sold a piece of property; 2 with his wife’s knowledge, he kept back some of the proceeds and brought only a part and laid it at the apostles’ feet. 3 “Ananias,” Peter asked, “why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit and to keep back part of the proceeds of the land? 4 While it remained unsold, did it not remain your own? evidence.id: The Good Shepherd and the Gate
evidence.short: John 10:1–18, Jesus: The Good Shepherd and the gate the shepherd will enter by
evidence.details:
10 “Very truly, I tell you, anyone who does not enter the sheepfold by the gate but climbs in by another way is a thief and a bandit. 2 The one who enters by the gate is the shepherd of the sheep. 3 The gatekeeper opens the gate for him, and the sheep hear his voice. He calls his own sheep by name and leads them out. 4 When he has brought out all his own, he goes ahead of them, and the sheep follow him because they know his voice. 5 They will not follow a stranger, but they will run from him because they do not know the voice of strangers.” 6 Jesus used this figure of speech with them, but they did not understand what he was saying to them.

7 So again Jesus said to them, “Very truly, I tell you, I am the gate for the sheep. 8 All who came before me[a] are thieves and bandits, but the sheep did not listen to them. 9 I am the gate. Whoever enters by me will be saved and will come in and go out and find pasture. 10 The thief comes only to steal and kill and destroy. I came that they may have life and have it abundantly.

11 “I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. 12 The hired hand, who is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep, sees the wolf coming and leaves the sheep and runs away, and the wolf snatches them and scatters them. 13 The hired hand runs away because a hired hand does not care for the sheep. 14 I am the good shepherd. I know my own, and my own know me, 15 just as the Father knows me, and I know the Father. And I lay down my life for the sheep. 16 I have other sheep that do not belong to this fold. I must bring them also, and they will listen to my voice. So there will be one flock, one shepherd. 17 For this reason the Father loves me, because I lay down my life in order to take it up again. 18 No one takes[b] it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it up again. I have received this command from my Father.”

evidence.short: Matthew 17:24–27 (and Clement of Alexandria): Jesus paid the temple tax only for himself and Peter
evidence.details: 24 When they reached Capernaum, the collectors of the temple tax came to Peter and said, “Does your teacher not pay the temple tax?” 25 He said, “Yes, he does.” And when he came home, Jesus spoke of it first, asking, “What do you think, Simon? From whom do kings of the earth take toll or tribute? From their children or from others?” 26 When Peter said, “From others,” Jesus said to him, “Then the children are free. 27 However, so that we do not give offense to them, go to the sea and cast a hook; take the first fish that comes up, and when you open its mouth you will find a coin; take that and give it to them for you and me.”

evidence.short: Matthew 17:27: Peter is the only one Jesus ever includes in a “we” or “us”

evidence.short: Matthew 18:18: All the apostles received the authority to bind and loose
evidence.details: 18 Truly I tell you, whatever you bind on earth will be bound in heaven, and whatever you loose on earth will be loosed in heaven.

evidence.short: Moses, David, Jesus, and Paul rightly asserted their God-given rights against those who opposed them
evidence.details: Kora rebelled against Moses; Saul, Absalom, and many others opposed David; the Jewish leaders opposed Jesus and got Him executed; Paul was opposed by the Judaizers. In all these cases, those whom God had commissioned were in the right, but to an onlooker, that might not always be that clear.

evidence.short: Peter is always listed first
evidence.details: The order the Twelve are listed in varies, but Simon Peter is always first, and Judas Iscariot always last.

evidence.short: Peter often speaks on behalf of all the apostles
evidence.details: Peter acts like a leader with actual authority, often without checking with the others first.

evidence.short: Arabic Canons of Nicæa (c. 10th century): Peter is head of Patriarchs and Vicar of Christ
evidence.details: The Arabic Canons of Nicaea (c. 10th century), a later and non-original text attributed to the First Council of Nicaea, state that Peter is the head of the Patriarchs and the Vicar of Christ. Though not part of the authentic 4th-century Nicene canons, this reflects a later Christian tradition emphasizing the primacy of Peter and, by extension, the authority of the bishop of Rome.

evidence.short: Eastern Churches consider the Pope "primus inter pares"
evidence.details: The Eastern Churches view the Pope as "primus inter pares", meaning "first among equals." This acknowledges the Pope’s honorary primacy among bishops but rejects his supreme authority over the entire Church, emphasizing a collegial and conciliar model of leadership.

evidence.short: The canons of Nicæa I suggest a regional jurisdiction
evidence.details: The canons of the First Council of Nicaea (325), particularly Canon 6, suggest a model of regional jurisdiction, affirming the authority of major bishops (like those of Rome, Alexandria, and Antioch) over their own territories. This shows that early Church structure might have lacked a centralized authority.

evidence.short: The Conciliar Movement and Gallicanism show Catholic skepticism of papal claims
evidence.details: The Conciliar Movement and Gallicanism reflect periods of Catholic skepticism toward papal authority. Both emphasized the authority of Church councils or national churches over the pope, challenging the idea of papal supremacy in the 14th to 18th centuries.

evidence.short: There were appeals to Rome early on, even in the East
evidence.details: Appeals to Rome, including from the Eastern Church, show a recognition of the bishop of Rome’s authority or moral weight in resolving disputes. While not always accepting Roman jurisdiction, these appeals show that Rome commanded respect in early Church matters.

evidence.id: Eastern Appealed to Patriarchs or Emperors
evidence.short: Eastern bishops often appealed to patriarchs or emperors instead of Rome
evidence.details: Eastern bishops often appealed to local patriarchs or the Byzantine emperor rather than to Rome, suggesting the choice of whom to appeal to was more pragmatic than anything else.

evidence.short: Pope Honorius I condemned for monothelitism
evidence.details: Pope Honorius I was condemned after his death for supporting monothelitism, a heresy that taught Christ had only one will (divine) instead of both a human and divine will. His condemnation came during the Third Council of Constantinople (680–681), which declared monothelitism heretical. Honorius was criticized not for teaching the heresy himself, but for failing to oppose it clearly and thus allowing it to spread.

evidence.short: Pope John XXII taught against the Beatific Vision for three years
evidence.details: Pope John XXII controversially taught for three years (1331–1334) that the souls of the righteous do not see the Beatific Vision (the direct sight of God) until the Final Judgment, contradicting traditional Catholic teaching. He retracted this view on his deathbed, and the teaching was officially corrected by his successor.

evidence.short: Pope Victor I threatened to excommunicate Asia Minor
evidence.details: In the late 2nd century, Pope Victor I threatened to excommunicate the churches of Asia Minor over a dispute about the date of Easter (the Quartodeciman controversy). Many bishops, including Irenæus of Lyons, urged him to reconsider. The excommunication was ultimately not enforced.

evidence.short: Pope Vigilius’s conflicting declarations on the Three Chapters
evidence.details: Pope Vigilius issued conflicting declarations on the Three Chapters controversy (6th century). He initially resisted condemnation, but later endorsed it under imperial pressure.

evidence.short: Rome preserved orthodoxy time and time again
evidence.details: Throughout history, Rome repeatedly defended orthodox teachings and was considered a bastion against heresy.
references: Will add source later. Probably Maximus the Confessor.

evidence.short: The Papacy has endured the test of time
evidence.details: The Papacy is one of the oldest current institutions in the world. It has survived centuries of political, religious, and social challenges to its existence and authority, and remains influential to this day.
references: Will add source later. I think.

evidence.short: Various forgeries were produced to buttress papal claims historically
evidence.details: Throughout history, various forgeries, like the Donation of Constantine and the Symmachian Forgeries, were produced to support and strengthen papal claims to religious authority and even temporal power. Though eventually discredited, some of them may have directly influenced Canon Law.

evidence.short: Various rulers and mobs have arguably deposed valid popes
evidence.details: Throughout history, various rulers and mobs have at times deposed or forced the resignation of valid popes, showing a certain disregard for papal authority.

evidence.short: Clement of Rome (c. 70–96 AD) asserted authority over Corinth in the mid–late first century, intervening in a leadership crisis to tell the laity to follow the clergy.
evidence.details:
Catholics often argue that this shows Rome's special leadership role even in the first century. The Apostle John was probably still alive on Patmos, which is much closer to Corinth than Rome is, but the Corinthians sought Rome's help instead.

Critics often point out that, although Corinth was in Greece, it was a Roman colony and enjoyed a close relationship to Rome itself. This means appealing to Rome might just have been the natural choice.

evidence.short: Ignatius of Antioch (c. 107–108 AD), who generally speaks "down" to the churches he writes on the way to his martyrdom, speaks "up" to the Romans, going so far as to say that Rome "presides over love" (i.e. the Eucharist).
evidence.details:
Catholics often argue that the reason Ignatius shows such respect for Rome is that St. Peter's office continues there, as evidenced by "presiding over love". "Love feast" is a common name for the Eucharist, so this fits very well with the modern Catholic understanding of being in communion with the Pope.

Critics often counter that Rome was an important city, Peter or no Peter, and Ignatius is writing to request that the Christians there avoid helping him escape martyrdom, so it is natural that he should be more polite.

evidence.short: Polycarp of Smyrna visited Rome to attempt a resolution of the Quartodeciman Controversy.
evidence.details:
Many of the (presumably Johannine) churches in Asia Minor celebrated Easter according to the Jewish calendar, no matter what day of the week it landed on, whereas the rest of the Church celebrated on a Sunday. This caused some controversy in the second century because it was felt that there should be a common Easter date for the whole Church.

Catholics argue that Polycarp travelling to Rome fits the Petrine leadership hypothesis.

Critics argue that Rome was the see complaining about this in the first place, which explains why Polycarp felt a need to travel there.

evidence.short: A church from c. 100 AD in Bethsaida, Peter's hometown, calls him 'chief and commander of the Heavenly Apostles'.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that 'chief and commander of the Heavenly Apostles' sounds a lot like the Papacy.

Critics argue that the church is built in Peter's honour, so of course it uses exalted language about him.

evidence.short: Dionysius of Corinth (c. 171 AD) praises Rome for uniting the churches of Rome and Corinth.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this shows the Pope's role as a uniter of the Church.

Critics argue that Corinth was a Roman colony and had a close relationship with Rome because of that.

evidence.short: Irenæus (c. 180 AD): All churches must agree with Rome.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this shows the central role of Rome in doctrinal questions, maybe even a precedent for Papal Infallibility.

Critics argue that this is merely an expression of respect for Rome's evident orthodoxy, not a belief that Rome is infallible.

evidence.short: Tertullian (pre-Montanism) and Origen both identified Peter as the rock on which the Church was to be built and the one to receive the keys in a way distinct from all others.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this shows that Peter's unique leadership role was known early on.

Critics generally look to the points below to diminish Peter's role.

Tertullian (c. 200): https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0311.htm
Tertullian (c. 203–206 AD): https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0318.htm
Tertullian (c. 208–212 AD): https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/0406.htm
Origen (c. 225 AD): https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/101505.htm
Origen (c. 233–244 AD): https://www.newadvent.org/fathers/101613.htm
Origen (c. 248 AD): https://www.churchfathers.org/origins-of-peter-as-pope

evidence.short: Tertullian, after becoming a Montanist heretic, mocks the Pope by sarcastically referring to him as "Pontifex Maximus" and "bishop of bishops".
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that Tertullian, as a heretic, would mock the Pope's authority because he didn't recognize it anymore.

Critics argue that this shows that the Pope was not the undisputed leader of the early Church.

evidence.short: Origen interpreted all Christians as a kind of Peter.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this is fine, because a passage can have several layers of meaning.

Critics argue that this undermines the papal aspects of identifying Peter as the rock.

evidence.short: Pope Anterus (c. 236) refers to the "apostolic seat".
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this is a very early reference to the chair of Peter as *the* apostolic seat.

Critics may see it as a special honour given to Peter's seat because he was the leader of the Twelve, or even just one of several apostolic seats.

evidence.id: Cyprian and the Equality of the Apostles
evidence.short: Cyprian of Carthage (c. 251–252 AD) says the apostles received equal power to bind and loose.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this is true, in the sense that the Pope is the leader of the college of bishops, but he doesn't replace the bishops.

Critics see this as incompatible with Papal Supremacy in general and Universal Jurisdiction in particular.

evidence.short: Cyprian of Carthage (c. 256 AD) opposed Pope Stephen, who threatened to excommunicate him over his rebaptism of converts from heretic groups.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this is an example where a saint is simply in the wrong, both doctrinally and hierarchically.

Critics see this as suggesting Rome was not the highest authority in the Church at this point.

evidence.id: Cyprian and the Unity of the Faith
evidence.short: Cyprian of Carthage (c. 252 AD) says the unity of the faith derives from the seat of Peter.
evidence.details:
The first edition of this book sounds a lot more "papal", but Cyprian toned it down for the second edition, where Peter is more of a model for every bishop.

Catholics see the first edition as an admission that Cyprian did recognize the Pope's authority.

Critics argue that he toned it down in the second edition to clarify what his actual stance was.

evidence.short: Ambrose of Milan (c. 340–397): Where Peter is, there is the Church.
evidence.details:
Catholics see this as clear evidence that the Pope is the locus of the Church's unity, and that being in communion with him is vital.

Critics argue that this can be understood to refer to any local bishop, not just the Pope.

evidence.short: Ambrose of Milan (c. 340–397) says the Petrine Primacy is one of confession, not of honor; a primacy of faith, not rank.
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this is true in the sense that the Church is built on Peter because of his confession, and that the "rank" refers to the Pope's role as servant of the servants of God.

Critics argue that this indicates the Pope is not above the other bishops in any way.

evidence.id: Several Fathers on the Rock and Keys
evidence.short:
Jerome (c. 376–377): "I know that this [chair of Peter] is the rock on which the Church is built"
Augustine (early) affirmed Peter as the rock.
Optatus of Milevis (c. 367 AD) affirmed Petrine primacy and sole holding of keys
evidence.details:
Catholics argue that this shows an awareness of Peter's (and therefore Rome's) special role.

Critics argue that Augustine changed his mind on this, which shows that this interpretation was not universally accepted.

evidence.short: Augustine of Hippo expressed his opinion that the controversy was over because it had been settled by several councils and sent to Rome.
evidence.details:
Augustine is often quoted as saying "Roma locuta est — causa finita est" ("Rome has spoken — the matter is finished"), but that is a simplified paraphrase. He actually says that two councils have decided against the Pelagians and sent their decisions to the Apostolic See, who has sent their rescripts back to Africa, and that the matter is finished.

Catholics argue that this shows that Rome was to be informed when a local controversy was settled, which makes sense if the Pope is the highest authority in the Church.

Critics say Rome had the most prestige (and even then, not always) of the major sees.
references: Augustine of Hippo (c. 354–430 AD): https://archive.org/details/saint-augustine-sermons/Saint Augustine - Sermons 94A %3B 147a/page/322/mode/2up?view=theater

evidence.short: Post-Nicene Western Fathers (average)
evidence.details: The Post-Nicene Western Fathers (4th to 6th centuries), such as St. Augustine and St. Ambrose, increasingly emphasized the authority and primacy of the bishop of Rome. They supported the idea of Rome as a central, guiding see in the Church, linking it to Peter’s role. They balanced this with respect for the broader episcopal college.
references: Will add sources later. Not sure how best to do this.

evidence.short: Post-Nicene Eastern Fathers (average)
evidence.details: The Post-Nicene Eastern Fathers (4th to 7th centuries), such as St. John Chrysostom and St. Cyril of Alexandria, show great respect for the bishop of Rome, but emphasized a conciliar and collegial Church authority. They recognized the importance of the Roman See but not to the point of embracing unilateral papal supremacy.
